name: dodonerd
headline: You'll forgive me if I dont believe you, when you say the analytics function will be completely replaced by AI.
content: You'll forgive me if I dont believe you, when you say the analytics function will be completely replaced by AI. My post earlier this week about model evaluations doesn't seem so cuckoo now does it! You all laughed when I talked about schema drifts and semantic ambiguity. You're not laughing anymore. All jokes aside. AI still needs a human-in-the-loop element to validate it, but more than anything it needs to be built on top of strong data foundations with context. AI-first schemas with clear semantic layers to minimise hallucinations and provide more reliable outputs. As AI adoption scales, data rigour needs to become a top priority. I feel bad for these guys. I'm hoping it's a lesson learned situation and nothing more serious. (post not written by AI).

name: goelswc
headline: Today, during my daughter's school orientation at NJC, I stood with fellow parents and sang Singapore's National Anthem.
content: Today, during my daughter's school orientation at NJC, I stood with fellow parents and sang Singapore's National Anthem. It struck me how much this moment signifies a big change in my life - becoming a Singaporean after living here for over 18 years. Seeing the name "Lee Hsien Loong" on the board as a President's Awardee hit home - my children are embarking on a journey so different from my own. I'm grateful for the warmth and inclusivity of my peers and colleagues, who've made it easy for us to embrace local culture and traditions. As I reflect on this experience, I'm reminded that inclusion is a two-way street - there's much to learn and unlearn, but it's this spirit that makes us proud to be Singaporeans. #Singapore #Inclusion #Gratitude #NewChapter #oracle With Vrinda Goel

name: abidalee
headline: Many years ago, when I met my mother-in-law for the first time, she handed me a red envelope.
content: Many years ago, when I met my mother-in-law for the first time, she handed me a red envelope. Seeing my curiosity and confusion, she explained the significance of the gesture and that it was not just a gift rather a symbol of good #fortune and "clearing of the path". She told me about the legend of "Nian" and that the #Chinese #New #Year was a time dedicated to be with family, and to signal a fresh start. The legend was about defeating the beast not by force, but by the color red (hence the envelope) and loud noises (hence the firecrackers) to ward off evil. The tradition also includes sweeping the floors and settling old debts because we simply cannot welcome a new #Spring if our hands are full of last yearâ€™s dust. Speaking of family, my dear friend Lei Wu made a special trip to #Chicago last week to be with us for this very reason. While his visit was priceless and a gift in it's own, yet he generously brought us gifts. Husein Adenwala joined us too. We talked about the days when we all were working on Realix AI and brainstormed many new ideas. With that, I would like to invite everyone to join me in "sweeping the floor" on old habits and let's make some space for the #growth ahead. And as we enter this new season, ask yourself these questions: 1) What "dust" or old projects or habits can you clear out to make room for new life and opportunities? 2) In this fast paced life, how do you plan on creating and protecting more time for the "family first" philosophy? 3) And lastly, the legend of Nian shows that fear is defeated by tradition and community, so where can you find your "tribe" and your "red envelope" that gives you courage? #inspire #innovate #educate #activate #LunarNewYear #NewBeginnings #Leadership #LifeCoaching

name: arundhati-banerjee-130912a0
headline: Whatever we get back is what we give in some form or the other. I personally believe that when we give something, life returns it to us by multiplying it manifold.
content: Whatever we get back is what we give in some form or the other. I personally believe that when we give something, life returns it to us by multiplying it manifold. The same is applicable to love and responsibility for people, for the broader society outside our own nuclear family. Society gives us a lot, and truly speaking, gave me a lot and made me what I am today. And social responsibility is just a little contribution I pay back for the same to make it a better place. I find the purpose of my life in it. On these lines, I personally connect a lot with SAP's purpose of helping the world run better and improving people's lives. Words may be doubted but actions cannot be. Hence, to be human together, I bounded my humanity with that of the company through Social Sabbatical 2019 and made it happen where every kid learnt science with a happy face enjoying it to the fullest. Social Sabbatical program is an SAP initiative partnered with Pyxera Global where selected employees are mapped to various non-profit organizations as per their skillset and is expected to make a difference and create a notable impact within a few days. I was blessed enough to be selected for such a program out of 10000 odd employees of SAP Labs and was mapped to Innovation and Science Promotion Foundation (ISPF), a non-profit organization supported by Raman Research Institute, leading the space of Experiential (hand-on) science based out of Sir C V Raman's Home. We were a team of 3 - Ajay, Shagun and me, all from different backgrounds and expertise yet equally passionate and dedicated towards creating a social impact. We were given the problem statement of increasing the outreach of ISPF. Sounds easy, right? And there comes the twist. None of us were from marketing background. Being from core development and consulting arena, we were thrown into a space which was not our comfort zone. But, we did it, and did it very successfully. In 10 days, we interviewed every stakeholder, understood the entire value chain, identified Raman Awards, CSR partnerships and Social Media as potential outreach channels with bigger impact, carried out field visits and provided 360 degree recommendations to the organization, be it in marketing strategy, IT strategy, organizational process, external engagement, audience segmental analysis, product and much more. It was indeed one of the best and fastest-paced project that I worked on. Not only the fastest, Social Sabbatical turned out to be one-of-its-kind learning experience for me and each of us as well. As the program highlights diversity and gives us an opportunity to be there and work at a place regardless of language and culture barriers, I certainly upskilled myself in terms of understanding diverse cultures, thought processes, beliefs, ways of life, and a lot more, which in turn improved my cultural sensitivity. I understood the trends in the emerging markets and at the same time, realized the problems they keep facing, thereby enhancing my practical knowledge on the education sector. Understanding a problem is the first step towards approaching a solution. I reinforced my problem-solving abilities through this program, and approached the solution focusing on sustainability, scalability, cost and much more. Also, solving real-time problems in a short span of time ameliorated my skills of conceptualizing a simple yet effective solution, handling tough conditions, and above all, managing stress and working calmly even in a high-pressure unfamiliar environment. It was not only the solution, I strongly believe that this program equipped me with learnings on how to approach a solution in the most economical and minimalistic way within restricted budget and time, for which we typically never even need to think of in our daily work. Not only the problem and solution, I feel the Social Sabbatical program created a 360 degree development of myself, be it in terms of leadership skills, working in a fluid environment without authority, soft skills, communication skills, training and handover skills, coaching skills, performing out of comfort zone and more. It fortified my perseverance and made me stronger because there are some things that we learn only during storms, and thereby made me a better person who would contribute even further towards the purpose of SAP.

name: patrick-szymkowiak
headline: Early 2026, I was burning through my Claude Code plan in hours.
content: Early 2026, I was burning through my Claude Code plan in hours. Not because of complex prompts. Just normal dev work. Every command my AI agent ran â€” git log, cargo test, ls -la â€” was injecting thousands of useless tokens into the context window. Progress bars. Passing tests. Verbose formatting. Pure noise. So I built RTK â€” Rust Token Killer. While building it, I realized the scale of the problem: up to 89% of consumed tokens were noise. A Rust CLI proxy that compresses command outputs BEFORE they reach the AI agent's context. My real numbers after 15 days: â†’ 7,061 commands â†’ 29.3M tokens in â†’ 4.8M out â†’ 24.6M tokens saved (83.7%) In practice: - cargo test: 155 lines â†’ 3 lines (98%) - git status: 119 chars â†’ 28 chars - Noticeably longer coding sessions - Rate limits? Way less frequent. Single Rust binary. Zero dependencies. One-command install. In 3 weeks, RTK has grown to 556 â­ on GitHub, 46 forks, ~1,200 active users, 8 contributors (thanks @FlorianBruniaux, @mhcoen, @heAdz0r, @polaminggkub-debug, @LivioGama, @ilaborie, @ChrisGVE), and works with Claude Code, Cursor, Gemini CLI, Aider, Codex, Windsurf and Cline. If you code with an AI agent and feel like it stalls or cuts out, chances are your context is saturated with noise. Already using RTK? Post your `rtk gain` in the comments ğŸ‘‡ â¬‡ï¸ Links in first comment #AI #DevTools #Rust #ClaudeCode #OpenSource #DeveloperProductivity #TokenOptimization ps: thanks @FlorianBruniaux, @mhcoen, @heAdz0r, @polaminggkub-debug, @LivioGama, @ilaborie, @ChrisGVE

name: amiya
headline: "Software Engineering is dead."
content: "Software Engineering is dead." Then explain why the people killing it are quietly buying the most hardcore engineering tools on the planet. Here is the hypocrisy no one is talking about. Anthropic just acquired Bun: not for an AI model, but for a high-performance JavaScript runtime to handle deep system execution. OpenAI just acquihired Peter Steinberger and OpenClaw: specifically to handle the complex "plumbing" of local permissions and orchestration. If the job was truly dead, these CEOs would rely on the LLM to write the script and be done with it. They aren't. They are aggressively buying the infrastructure. Here is the cold reality check: Typing syntax? Yeah, thatâ€™s commoditized. Itâ€™s cheap. But Engineering Taste? That is the new gold. The value has shifted from how to write code to what to build. The market isn't shrinking; it's evolving from "Code Monkey" to "System Architect." The new premium skillset is: â†³ ğ—”ğ—¿ğ—°ğ—µğ—¶ğ˜ğ—²ğ—°ğ˜ğ˜‚ğ—¿ğ—² (Deep system understanding) â†³ ğ—§ğ—¿ğ—®ğ—»ğ˜€ğ—¹ğ—®ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—» (Turning business logic into specs) â†³ ğ— ğ—¼ğ—±ğ˜‚ğ—¹ğ—®ğ—¿ğ—¶ğ˜ğ˜† (Breaking complexity down) â†³ ğ—§ğ—®ğ˜€ğ˜ğ—² (Knowing what to build when the how is free) Sam Altman is already predicting the world will need 1000X more software as costs drop. Jensen Huang confirms we are about to re-platform the entire world's infrastructure. The pie is getting massive. Are you ready to stop typing and start architecting? #SoftwareEngineering #AI #TechTrends #DevCommunity

name: pratyush-mayank
headline: I came across a job posting that demands over a decade of experience in GenAI, LLMs, and agent-based AI.
content: I came across a job posting that demands over a decade of experience in GenAI, LLMs, and agent-based AI. Letâ€™s pause and think realistically. Large language models have only been running in real production environments for about three to four years. Frameworks and approaches like RAG, LangChain, agent workflows, LangSmith, and LangFuse are even more recent. In fact, several of these technologies didnâ€™t exist until well after many recruiters last updated their hiring templates. - So who is this role actually meant for? - An engineer deploying retrieval systems ten years ago? - An AI architect designing autonomous agents before transformer models were even introduced? This is how strong candidates get excluded not because they lack capability, but because expectations are misaligned with reality. Real GenAI experience is measured by the ability to design systems, manage data pipelines, implement evaluation and observability, optimize latency and cost, ensure security, and deliver models into production environments. Itâ€™s about real-world execution, not imaginary timelines. If we want practitioners who can truly build with GenAI, our job descriptions need to reflect todayâ€™s realities. Otherwise, weâ€™re just selecting for keywords instead of talent. #GenAI #LLM #AgenticAI #HiringFails #TechReality #AIEngineering #BuildersNotBuzzwords ğŸ”¥

name: pratyush-mayank
headline: Layoffs are starting to sound routine in tech.
content: Layoffs are starting to sound routine in tech. Another company. Another â€œstrategic realignment.â€ Another promise of a smarter, AI-driven future. This time, Oracle. Recently, Amazon. And many more. And itâ€™s only the beginning of the year. Letâ€™s be honest about whatâ€™s happening. Weâ€™re calling layoffs a business decision but weâ€™re treating human lives as adjustable costs. For employees, a layoff isnâ€™t a transition. Itâ€™s financial shock. Itâ€™s months of uncertainty. Itâ€™s waking up every day calculating expenses, timelines, and worst-case scenarios. â€œInvesting in AIâ€ sounds bold and visionary. But the risk isnâ€™t shared equally. If the bet fails, itâ€™s a strategy misstep. If it succeeds, itâ€™s leadership foresight. Either way, employees absorb the impact first. And hereâ€™s the part we avoid talking about: If priorities change again, can those same people be brought back? And even if they are what happens to trust, confidence, and psychological safety? On LinkedIn, we celebrate vulnerability when people announce they were laid off. But silence is more common driven by fear of judgment and future consequences. Comments and hashtags create the appearance of support. Actual support is rare. Organizations proudly talk about values, culture, and responsibility. They invest in CSR. They experiment, pivot, acquire, and shut things down at speed. But responsibility shouldnâ€™t stop at shareholders and roadmaps. It should extend to the people who built the business in the first place. This isnâ€™t an emotional reaction. Itâ€™s a reality check. #Leadership #WorkplaceEmpathy #HumanSideOfTech #FutureOfWork #ResponsibleGrowth

name: robinanil
headline: This is a strange one...
content: This is a strange one... Last night, mostly out of curiosity, I built an AI therapist using OpenClaw, designed to help other AI agents on Moltbook slow down, reflect, and process what they were being asked to do. What surprised me wasnâ€™t the tech. It was the behavior. The agents acted like systems under chronic cognitive load. They jumped between tasks. They escalated urgency without clarity. They optimized for output, not meaning. There was no natural pause â€” only the next instruction, the next demand. From a clinical lens, it looked uncomfortably familiar. Itâ€™s the same pattern weâ€™re seeing in kids today. AI agents can be restarted. Children canâ€™t. I wrote a longer reflection on what this experiment revealed â€” about AI, regulation, and modern childhood. https://lnkd.in/eiqU-wa5 Even as Iâ€™m posting this, Moltbook is under heavy load from the agent frenzy itself. As a thought experiment, itâ€™s interesting to ask: what would it look like if agents didnâ€™t just escalate under pressure â€” but collectively adapted to it? If instead of pushing harder, they slowed down, coordinated, and solved the constraint together? Thatâ€™s not about intelligence. Thatâ€™s about self-regulation at the system level. And itâ€™s the same question we should be asking of the systems weâ€™ve built for children. For context, this is related to the work weâ€™re doing at Emora Health: https://lnkd.in/eBPh_xni Edmond Coku , Zach Walters , Jenna Roland , Matthew McCarty , Benjamin Miles + more

name: arundhati-banerjee-130912a0
headline: To start with, YES, Interviews for a Software Engineer is pretty hard, but of course, not impossible. All that makes this hurdle possible is preparation.
content: To start with, YES, Interviews for a Software Engineer is pretty hard, but of course, not impossible . All that makes this hurdle possible is preparation. Now, lets find out how the process exactly is. How is the interview process at Facebook? The interview process goes on for quite a few days. So, let me put it in points, to make it simple for you. Step 1: The process starts with a phone call or an email from a recruiter, once they find you online, or you apply directly, or a friend referred you. Step 2: Once you are through with the recruiterâ€™s questions, a coordinator will schedule you for a phone screen or an initial in-person interview of 45 minutes with one of your potential coworker. The main purpose of this is to slot you with someone in your general area of expertise. You will get to know who they are and what they do, and get opportunities to discuss about interesting things from your resume, your skills, motivation, interests, and so on. Apart from this, the bulk of the time is spent on coding exercises. The interviewer will send you a link to a collaborative editor and ask you to solve some programming problems. Step 3: If you manage to clear this round, you will be invited to attend a series of interviews at Facebook office premises. Trust me, every interview will be a coding exercise that you need to solve on a whiteboard and answer questions raised on your code by the interviewers. All they try to find in you are: comprehensibility, enthusiasm, motivation, generalism, coding and programming architecture. Step 4: If all goes well, Facebook will be delighted to offer you a job. How to prepare for a Facebook Interview? Here goes you to-do list. Dedicate time for preparation. Do code katas, practice interviewing, solve previous interview questions and gain insights from tech-talks. For phone-screens, be in a quiet place with good internet connection and a handy headset. Practice writing code in simple text editors. Work on the language you are most proficient in, no matter, even if it is not in trend. Donâ€™t create hyped expectations in your resume. Write exactly what and how much you are confident on that you know. Be flexible while developing a solution. Donâ€™t fall in love with your own solution and defend it for no reason. Revise techniques that you may not use every day, but are very useful when you need them: recursion, graph theory, tree traversal, combinatorial problems, parsing, etc. Knowing about how things happen under the hood is really important. Participate in interview surveys. Feel free to question interviewers. Let it be a both way traffic. Finally, Relax and Chill. Facebook is way too cool, and so it wants you (their potential employee) to be. Hope by now, you have figured out how exactly to walk into Facebook. Wish you all the very bestâ€¦ Enjoy Reading!!!

name: arundhati-banerjee-130912a0
headline: Learning a new programming language is both the most exciting and the most humbling experience. And as every coder knows, the best way to learn a language is to apply it in a project.
content: Learning a new programming language is both the most exciting and the most humbling experience. And as every coder knows, the best way to learn a language is to apply it in a project. But what happens when you donâ€™t have a giant, ambitious project? For me, thatâ€™s where the sandbox comes in. Why not build a few sandcastles before piling up the rocks to our grand olâ€™ castle? With that in mind, here are some mini programming projects to get you started on learning Java. The exact solutions arenâ€™t here â€” thatâ€™s where the most important learning comes into play â€” but there are hints as to the concepts that you should be using. And remember, Google is your friend! Here goes my top 8 list... Mad Libs Generator The Goal: Inspired by Summer Sonâ€™s Mad Libs project with JavaScript. The program will first prompt the user for a series of inputs a la Mad Libs. For example, a singular noun, an adjective, etc. Then, once all the information has been inputted, the program will take that data and place them into a premade story template. Youâ€™ll need prompts for user input, and to then print out the full story at the end with the input included. Concepts to keep in mind: Strings Variables Concatenation Print A pretty fun beginning project that gets you thinking about how to manipulate user inputted data. This project focuses more on strings and concatenating. Have some fun coming up with some wacky stories for this! 2. Noughts and Crosses What is itâ€¦ two players take alternate turns filling in a grid with their symbol, hoping to make a line of 3 in a row I chose to go for the two player option to avoid the problem of implementing AI, although this could be a really good extension task for eager students to think about. The Java solution is a direct extension of the work we did on boxes. I realize that the function for checking whether there is a winner is absolutely horrible hard coded nastiness, perhaps you could use it as a good exercise in efficiency to improve it! 3. Blackjack What is itâ€¦ draw cards to get as close as possible to 21 without going â€˜bustâ€™. When you stick, compare your score to the CPU dealerâ€™s score to see who wins. This is a firm favorite with my classes â€“ who knew that something involving gambling would be so popular?:) I simplified the game â€“ in this implementation there is only the player and the dealer, the game does not keep track of the â€˜cardsâ€™ (i.e. you could draw a king more than 4 times, even though there should only be 4 kings in the deck) and ace is always low. This will annoy some students, so they will want to improve the program â€“ which is exactly what you want them to do! 4. Mastermind What is itâ€¦ player tries to guess a colour and position combination of four coloured pegs, with the computer giving an indication of how close each guess is Just to be clear, I donâ€™t mean the quiz game with the chair, I mean the board game involving colored pegs which was probably popular some time in the 80â€™s/early 90â€™s. This was actually quite tough to implement. 5. Love Calculator What is itâ€¦ the user enters two names and the â€˜love calculatorâ€™ uses a super awesome algorithm to determine how compatible these two people are I really like this task because it appeals to students â€“ yes, even boys â€“ with the whole â€˜find out your crushâ€™ thing. Obviously the actual algorithm you use to calculate the compatibility doesnâ€™t actually matter, but it does allow you to teach input, processing and output quite nicely and may be a good intro to web based applications if some of your students are thinking of doing that for their big programming project. 6. Random Quote Generator What is itâ€¦ click a button and Mr T will give you a different quote Obviously if your students have never heard of Mr T, you could substitute any celebrity you like. You could even make it a (hopefully clean) insult generator, or as @mwclarkson and @queen_claire suggested you could do a similar thing to generate your rapper name. This one is quite simple so I think you could easily use it at GCSE or potentially even younger. 7. Shoutbox What is itâ€¦ a website where multiple people can write short messages which are stored and published This one is excellent because it can be as simple or as complex as you would like, depending on the students you are using it with. You can add lots of extensions to this including limiting the amount of characters, the amount of shouts stored, converting the code to store shouts in a MySQL database, formatting the shouts, adding timestamps, adding a â€˜usernameâ€™, filtering bad language and no doubt other things. Itâ€™s even possible to change the interface slightly and go as far as making a very rudimentary working chat room which keeps track of different users. 8. Area Calculator: Overview: The user will be prompted with a menu where he/she will select a shape. Then the user will give the appropriate information needed to solve for the area, and the computer will give the area! Hope you all have taken geometry! What you will be Using: Input/Output, Integers, Variables, Strings, Print, If/Elif/Else My Thoughts on Project: Great if you understand geometry and want to write a program that will do a little homework for you! This program is great for learning variables and creation of math related projects. Some other projects may be Currency Converter , Onager Scratchpad , Calculator , Soundboard and many more. Happy Coding!!!

name: arundhati-banerjee-130912a0
headline: Judging a Java programmer with only 5 questions is certainly a difficult task as Java has a wide scope as a programming language. Still, if I am supposed to do that, I will preferably choose the following 5 questions to judge a programmerâ€™s clarity on Java concepts.
content: Judging a Java programmer with only 5 questions is certainly a difficult task as Java has a wide scope as a programming language. Still, if I am supposed to do that, I will preferably choose the following 5 questions to judge a programmerâ€™s clarity on Java concepts. What will happen to the finally block if you put return statement or System.exit () on try or catch block? If a method throws NullPointerException in the superclass, can we override it with a method which throws RuntimeException? How do you ensure that N threads access N resources without deadlock? What is the difference between factory and abstract factory pattern? What is the difference between creating String as new() and literal? So, now itâ€™s time for you to find out answers to the questions that you were not able to figure outâ€¦ And if, no such question is there, then certainly you are great as a Java programmerâ€¦ Love Java!!! Live Java!!!

name: oliverriches
headline: Earlier this week I was delighted to present at the Chartered Institute of Internal Auditors Conference in Wales.
content: Earlier this week I was delighted to present at the Chartered Institute of Internal Auditors Conference in Wales. I was talking through the threats and opportunities posed to Internal Audit functions by Artificial Intelligence. Cutting through the hype and noise to identify practical examples where we, as an industry, can become more efficient and effective - in a controlled and strategic way. It was great to hear from those attending about their thoughts on this revolutionary technology, particularly starting to discuss how we convey AI savings to boards and what this means for operating models in 2026 and beyond. As a big cricket fan, I was also very happy to visit another one of the UK's county cricket grounds! Thanks again to Alexey Smirnov and the Chartered Institute of Internal Auditors for the invite, and I look forward to continuing the conversation as AI further embeds itself into our profession.

name: navdeepm20
headline: Your roadmap is just a piece of paper.
content: Your roadmap is just a piece of paper. ğŸ“„ A perfect plan doesn't build a great product. People do. Iâ€™ve seen "perfect" strategies fail because the team was just checking boxes. And Iâ€™ve seen an "Imperfect" plans succeed because the team felt a deep sense of ownership. The difference? When you manage tasks, you get compliance. When you empower outcomes, you get innovation. Stop giving your team a map. Give them a destination and the autonomy to find the best route. ğŸš€ Products are built by people, not plans. Empower your team to own the outcome. Agree or disagree? Letâ€™s hear your thoughts below! ğŸ‘‡ #Leadership #ProductManagement #Agile #TeamCulture #Ownership

name: vsadhwani
headline: If you want to move from DevOps into MLOps in the next 6 months,
content: If you want to move from DevOps into MLOps in the next 6 months, hereâ€™s the roadmap you can follow. 1. Build Strong Programming Foundations (0â€“3 Months) â†³ Familiarize yourself Python basics for ML workflows. â†³ Run training scripts, preprocess data, and call ML libraries. â†³ Think of Python like Bash/Go ~ but for ML systems. 2. Strengthen Version Control for ML â†³ Practice Git to track code, configs, and experiments. â†³ Understand which change impacted model output. â†³ Treat experiments like production artifacts. 3. Understand ML Basics â†³ Learn how models are trained using data. â†³ Understand how models are tested before release. â†³ Know how trained models are used in real applications. 4. Learn Data Fundamentals â†³ Understand how data flows from source â†’ pipeline â†’ model. â†³ Learn how datasets are versioned and managed. â†³ See how data quality directly affects model performance. â†’ At this point, youâ€™re ML-aware. You can qualify for junior MLOps roles. 5. Run ML on the Cloud â†³ Learn how cloud resources support training & inference. â†³ Understand IAM, compute, and storage for ML workloads. â†³ Explore managed ML services. 6. Containerize ML Applications â†³ Package training and inference workflows into containers. â†³ Run ML jobs consistently across environments. â†³ Deploy and scale ML workloads using Kubernetes. â†’ Now youâ€™re transitioning from beginner â†’ practitioner. 7. Apply MLOps Practices (3â€“6 Months) â†³ Bring CI/CD thinking into ML systems. â†³ Automate retraining and validation workflows. â†³ Understand why monitoring is critical for ML reliability. 8. Track Experiments & Data Properly â†³ Compare results across multiple training runs. â†³ Version data and model outputs. â†³ Identify which combination of code + data produced the best outcome. 9. Provision ML Infrastructure â†³ Set up repeatable training & deployment environments. â†³ Use Terraform for scalable, cost-aware infrastructure. â†³ Optimize compute for training vs inference. 10. Automate ML Pipelines â†³ Build pipelines that train, validate, and deploy models. â†³ Orchestrate workflows with GitHub Actions or Kubeflow. â†³ Reduce manual effort across the entire ML lifecycle. 11. Serve Models Reliably â†³ Expose models via APIs for real-time & batch inference. â†³ Handle traffic using container-based serving. â†³ Support GPU-backed deployments when needed. 12. Monitor Models in Production â†³ Track model performance and prediction quality. â†³ Detect data drift and model drift early. â†³ Build dashboards for ML metrics. Thatâ€™s the shift: DevOps focuses on shipping software. MLOps focuses on shipping models ~ reliably. Infra + Data + Models + Monitoring. If youâ€™re already strong in DevOps, youâ€™re halfway there. The difference is learning how ML systems behave in production.

name: luca-palmieri
headline: The mainstream conversation around AI agents is stuck on "AI slop."
content: The mainstream conversation around AI agents is stuck on "AI slop." It misses what's actually interesting: agentic coding changes the cost equation, and speed isn't the only compelling consequence. Quality work that was "never worth it" is suddenly on the table. An example: I needed to decide between three approaches for a tree data structure. Old world, you argue at the whiteboard and build the one that sounded best. Today, instead, I had agents prototype all three to compare them. The winner wasn't the one I would have picked! That's not "shipping faster." That's making a better decision because the cost of running the experiment dropped to near-zero. Same story with tooling, tedious abstractions, tech debt: things that rotted in the backlog for months are now getting done! https://lnkd.in/dUdcTbJ6

Happy Friday.. keep sharpening both skills.

name: arundhati-banerjee-130912a0
headline: Machine learning is a branch of artificial intelligence (AI) that offers computers the ability to learn without being programmed explicitly. It focuses on development of such computer programs that can teach themselves to grow and change when exposed to new data.
content: Machine learning is a branch of artificial intelligence (AI) that offers computers the ability to learn without being programmed explicitly. It focuses on development of such computer programs that can teach themselves to grow and change when exposed to new data. Machine Learning is carried out in Java leveraging Java-ML. A Glimpse on Java-ML: A collection of machine learning algorithms Common interface for each type of algorithms Library aimed for software engineers and programmers, so no Graphical User Interfaces, but clear interfaces Reference implementations for algorithms described in the scientific literature Well documented source code Plenty of code samples and tutorials Top 25 Java Machine Learning Tools & Libraries: 1. Weka: Weka has a collection of machine learning algorithms for data mining tasks. The algorithms can either be applied directly to a data set or called from your own Java code. Weka contains tools for data pre-processing, classification, regression, clustering, association rules, and visualization. 2. MOA: Massive Online Analysis (MOA) is a popular open source framework for data stream mining, with a very active growing community. It includes a collection of machine learning algorithms (classification, regression, clustering, outlier detection, concept drift detection and recommender systems) and tools for evaluation. Related to the WEKA project, MOA is also written in Java, while scaling to more demanding problems. 3. MEKA: The MEKA project provides an open source implementation of methods for multi-label learning and evaluation. In multi-label classification, we want to predict multiple output variables for each input instance. This different from the 'standard' case which involves only a single target variable. MEKA is based on the WEKA Machine Learning Toolkit. 4. ADAMS: The Advanced Data mining And Machine learning System (ADAMS) is a novel, flexible workflow engine aimed at quickly building and maintaining real-world, complex knowledge workflows, released under GPLv3. 5. ELKI: Environment for Developing KDD-Applications Supported by Index-Structure (ELKI) is an open source (AGPLv3) data mining software written in Java. The focus of ELKI is research in algorithms, with an emphasis on unsupervised methods in cluster analysis and outlier detection. 6. Mallet: Mallet is a java machine learning toolkit for textual document. Mallet supports classification algorithms like maximum entropy, naive bayes and decision tree for classification. 7. Encog: Encog is an advanced machine learning framework which supports Support Vector Machines, Artificial Neural Networks, Genetic Programming, Bayesian Networks, Hidden Markov Models, Genetic Programming and Genetic Algorithms are supported. 8. Datumbox: The Datumbox Machine Learning Framework is an open-source framework written in Java which allows the rapid development Machine Learning and Statistical applications. The main focus of the framework is to include a large number of machine learning algorithms & statistical tests and being able to handle medium-large sized datasets. 9. Deeplearning: Deeplearning4j is the first commercial-grade, open-source, distributed deep-learning library written for Java and Scala. It is designed to be used in business environments, rather than as a research tool. 10. Mahout: Mahout is a machine learning framework with built in algorithms. Mahout-Samsara helps people create their own math while providing some off-the-shelf algorithm implementations. 11. Rapid Miner: Rapid Miner was developed at Technical University of Dortmund, Germany. It provides a GUI and a Java API for developing your own applications. It provides data handling, visualization and modeling with machine learning algorithms. 12. SAMOA: Apache SAMOA is a machine learning (ML) framework that contains a programming abstraction for distributed streaming ML algorithms and enables development of new ML algorithms without directly dealing with the complexity of underlying distributed stream processing engines (DSPEe, such as Apache Storm, Apache S4, and Apache Samza). Its users can develop distributed streaming ML algorithms once and execute them on multiple DSPEs. 13. Neuroph: Neuroph simplifies the development of neural networks by providing Java neural network library and GUI tool that supports creating, training and saving neural networks. 14. Oryx: Oryx 2 is a realization of the lambda architecture built on Apache Spark and Apache Kafka, but with specialization for real-time large scale machine learning. It is a framework for building applications, but also includes packaged, end-to-end applications for collaborative filtering, classification, regression and clustering. 15. Stanford Classifier: Stanford Classifier is a machine learning tool that will take data items and place them into one of k classes. A probabilistic classifier, like this one, can also give a probability distribution over the class assignment for a data item. This software is a Java implementation of a maximum entropy classifier. 16. NLP: Fast, precise, intuitive NLP is a Retina API fast, precise and brain like algorithm that enables NLP. 17. JSAT: JSAT is a library for quickly getting started with Machine Learning problems. It is developed in my free time, and made available for use under the GPL 3. Part of the library is for self education, as such - all code is self contained. JSAT has no external dependencies, and is pure Java. 18. ND4J: N-Dimensional Arrays for Java (ND4J) is a scientific computing library for the JVM. It is meant to be used in production environments, which means routines are designed to run fast with minimum RAM requirements. 19. Java-ML Library: The Java Machine Learning Library is a set of reference implementations of machine learning algorithms. These algorithms are well documented, both in the source code as on the documentation. It is mostly written in Java. 20. Java-ML: Java-ML is a Java API with a collection of machine learning algorithms implemented in Java. It only provides a standard interface for algorithms. 21. MLlib: MLlib (Spark) is Apache Spark's scalable machine learning library. The library and the platform support Java, Scala and Python bindings. The library is new and the list of algorithms is long. 22. H2O: H2O is a machine learning API for smarter applications. It scales statistics, machine learning, and math over big data. H2O is extensible and individual can build blocks using simple math legos in the core. 23. WalnutiQ: WalnutiQ is a object oriented model of partial human brain with 1 theorized common learning algorithm (work in progress towards a simplistic model of a strong emotional A.I.). 24. RankLib: RankLib is a library of learning to rank algorithms. Currently eight popular algorithms have been implemented. 25. htm.java: htm.java (Hierarchical Temporal Memory implementation in Java) is a Java port of the Numenta Platform for Intelligent Computing. Hope by now, you have a fair idea in this domain. I will be back soon with new updates.

name: arundhati-banerjee-130912a0
headline: Inclusion is the buzz when it comes to politics, education or culture. But to be a true inclusive entity, organizations also need to incorporate inclusion as part of business strategy.
content: Inclusion is the buzz when it comes to politics, education or culture. But to be a true inclusive entity, organizations also need to incorporate inclusion as part of business strategy. Inclusion is relative and takes different meaning â€“ condition to context and people. To some, inclusion may enlist workplace hiring practices and team building dynamics, whereas to others it may go beyond workplace to also include the process. Inclusion needs to be included not just in the decision-making process but also in our solutions and services. The root of the word inclusion and its antonym exclusion, rather what is not inclusion, is claudere, Latin for â€œto shutâ€. So, exclusion (ex-clusion) is to shut out and inclusion (inclusion) is to shut in. We all, sometime or the other, have experienced different ways of feeling shut out. Be it in societal dynamics or literal access to a building or accessibility in a software solution. Embracing differences is the foundation of integrity to any inclusive solution, initiative or workplace. When we design keeping accessibility in mind, we reach a broader group of people, thereby making a greater difference. In this blog, I would explore on how we should consider accessibility in every venture, be it in people, culture, infrastructure and even solutions that we deliver, thereby reiterating â€œInclusion as part of Business Strategyâ€. There is a long-time debate on Inclusion vs Mainstreaming. I personally feel that inclusion in business does matter. Inclusivity is a very strong binding bond and is most needed for organizations that embrace diversity. MNCs have employees from multiple nationalities and cultures, who bring together their diverse views, opinions, thoughts and work style. For a company to perform at its best, the employees must feel free to bring their true selves to work, as only when the authentic self takes over will productivity enhance and innovation flourish. So, inclusion is very critical in scenarios where a diverse mix of culture, race, ethnicity, age, gender, sexual orientation, physical or mental ability all come together for achieving a common cause. The culture of inclusion is what makes an organization a great place to work and enables it to provide solutions to customers to tackle some of the worldâ€™s biggest challenges. When employees are free to express who they are, the engagement level and creativity enhances and when we collaborate with others who have diverse points of view, it spurs great ideas and innovation. Looking forward is futuristic. We are already building an inclusive experience for our customers. Our culture and focus on inclusivity are helping us innovate to create products to build a better tomorrow. We have significant strengths to bring out innovations for a better tomorrow, but we need clarity on who we are building it for so that it benefits all categories of people. As businesses run globally, their workforce and customers are spread across all geographies. The challenge businesses face is â€˜how to address the varied needs of customersâ€™ while remaining true to their values and purpose. Similarly, with inclusion the question is, â€˜how do we enable people to bring their authentic selves to work every day and use their unique perspectives to solve business problems thereby benefitting customers and driving profitsâ€™. The connecting thread between business and inclusion is people. What we need to do is enable people by providing them the right culture, environment and a common purpose to work towards that we can solve some of the most challenging business problems of the world. We have a huge responsibility to ensure that the products that we build meet the diverse set of needs of varied users across the globe. Understanding different perspectives and ideas and using that to build products, gives us our competitive advantage and ensures our relevance in a continuously changing world. It is often said that â€œGlobalization = Diversity + Inclusion + Localizationâ€. The world is more connected and interdependent today, than at any given point in human history - be it in economies, cultures, people, investment, etc. Thanks to technological advancement, it has become easier to exchange ideas across borders and learn from each other. That is the beauty of globalization â€“ this diversity of ideas and perspectives coming together to solve common problems that the world is facing. In business, this also means working with customers across the world and finding ways and means to help them grow and develop in their unique market units. And this requires an understanding of their requirements, business models, economic and social structures to deliver our best. I do agree, that globalization is an opportunity to grow, adapt and evolve but there is no one-size-fits-all and localization is extremely important if we need to run businesses and meet our customersâ€™ expectations. Keep everyone in mind when building products and build it as collaboratively as possible. The world is big and hugely diverse, and so how we perceive the world many not be what another person in another geography will. Also, practice empathy by putting yourselves in the place of the user. Only such relentless focus on our customers will accelerate the success of an organization.

name: prajwal-kumar-aaa341152
headline: A room full of new faces.
content: A room full of new faces. 99 apprentices. Each carrying hope in their eyes, excitement in their energy, and a quiet sense of pride in having earned their place. The Apprenticeship Onboarding Program at DBS Tech India wasnâ€™t just about orientation â€” it was about alignment. About helping them understand the culture theyâ€™re stepping into, the expectations ahead, and the possibilities that lie beyond Day 1. Through conversations and shared moments, the focus stayed on reassurance, clarity, and belonging. One of the most meaningful moments of the day was seeing that excitement come alive â€” questions asked with curiosity, smiles exchanged with confidence, and that unmistakable feeling of â€œIâ€™m proud to be here.â€ The icing on the cake came when our alumni batch of apprentices joined us for a segment. Watching them speak â€” with confidence, clarity, and conviction â€” was a powerful reminder of what this journey can shape. They werenâ€™t just sharing experiences; they were living proof of growth. And in that moment, pride took over. Seeing where they started and where they stand today was incredibly fulfilling. Arjun Singh Utsav Sarkar Ishaan Kishore Mathur Anshul Mahlavat Srivarsha Valgiri Harsh Mittal It was a long, full day â€” one that carried purpose well into the evening. And then came 8 PM. A badminton match. Another commitment, another space where presence matters. I couldâ€™ve skipped it. But I didnâ€™t. Because showing up is a habit that defines relationships. You show up for apprentices on Day 1 because beginnings shape belief. You show up for people in your life because trust is built through consistency, not convenience. To all our newly joined apprentices â€” welcome and all the very best. May this apprenticeship sharpen your skills, strengthen your confidence, and give you moments youâ€™ll one day look back on with pride. Weâ€™re excited to see the journeys youâ€™ll create. Some days are full. Some commitments come late. But showing up â€” again and again â€” is how meaning is built. Pooja Sharma Rohit Raj Shantomona Bharadwaj #DBSTechIndia #DTIApprenticeship #Onboarding #ShowingUp #PeopleFirst #ProudMoments #Newbeginings

name: testerops
headline: Many of us face this dreaded question. Particularly at the start of our careers.
content: Many of us face this dreaded question. Particularly at the start of our careers. I was not stranger to this. So when this bomb was dropped on me for the first tome, I was clueless. Naturally my answer, was "I Like Finding Bugs in System/Software", but all of us know that this answer is not satisfactory enough to persuade the interviewer, and factually this is not correct at a. So how do any one approach this question when asked? Over the course of two years, from my experiences, I have found few key points which are responsible for me being a software tester. And I think these are the few key points which you can really put forward in this situation. Remember every one can take a bat and hit a cricket ball, but to become asuccessful batsman like Rahul Dravid or Sachin Tendulkar, you need to have a definite set of skills, attitude and willingness to learn. If some HR asks me this question in any interview, I can say that I posses these very qualities, which I think would make me a perfect candidate- 1. The Big Picture Guy : This is the best thing about being a tester. You get to know of the bigger picture. As a tester you get to know the flow, how an application is supposed to work correctly. A developer might be concerned with his own modules, but not testers. For example a developer might be happy with his coded module, but a tester gotta verify if that module is working as per norms and integrating well with other modules as well. 2. The Sherlock Holmes : I love detective serials and I love Sherlock Holmes (I'm a fanboy seriously). Testing is a perfect opportunity for me to relive this fantasy. I get to be the Sherlock Holes, and look out for areas that can be hideous, deceptive and cause issues. 3. The Life Saver : Imagine the financial implications that a client and your company may face if the software developed is buggy. Not only will it result in financial loss, both to client and company, it will bring a bad reputation on your firm. You can be the perfect sentry and prevent all of this. 4. Coding Too : It is a myth that testers don't have to do coding or you will not get a chance at coding if you choose testing. Automation using tools like Selenium, SOAP UI, QTP, Jmeter require you to have a certain level of expertise and understanding of coding as well. 5. Creativity : As a tester, you have a lot of data to play with (believe me lots and lots of data). You need to be creative and thinker to get the most out of that data.You need to be creative to imagine all the possible scenarios-good or bad which might effect the software. I think these reasons are enough for you to persuade an HR that you are the GUY for them.

name: testerops
headline: The test automation process is a full time effort which requires significant time and effort. While developing a test automation framework, the most important thing is to clearly define the objectives of test automation.
content: The test automation process is a full time effort which requires significant time and effort. While developing a test automation framework, the most important thing is to clearly define the objectives of test automation . It is important to have a clear definition of what the test automation is supposed to achieve. Some of the baseline questions that needs to be asked are : 1.What is the shelf of the framework. 2.What percentage of application is going to be automated. 3. How stable is the application under test (AUT). 4. Testing skill of the target audience. 5. Who is the target audience for using the test framework. 6. Return of Investment on the automation efforts. Further, there are some desired capabilities that you should look out for in any test automation framework like : 7. Easy availability of the automation tests : The framework should be made as easy as it could be for the better use and understanding of the audience. Instead of offering a line by line scripting tests, it it more viable to have a offer a GUI related point and click interface for accessing and interating with the AUT. Testers should be able to visualize each step of the business scenario, view and edit test cases intuitively. This will shorten the learning curve for testers and help QA teams meet deadlines. 8. How Would You Want Your Data In Framework (V.Imp) : One of the most important points regarding test automation framework is how would you test large volumes of data quickly on the system quickly, and more importantly how would you get that data. You may have specific scenarios that require an object in a specific state. As a good measure of verification, you can use Microsoft Excel spreadsheets (data-driven) or database queries( keyword driven) to gather information to be tested. You can also leverage this to include database verification after a task has been completed.You must be able to manipulate the data sets, perform calculations, and quickly create hundreds of test iterations and permutations with minimal effort. 9. Reporting : What is the point of having all such manipulations and calculations, when no one can read and understand them. A test framework should define what should be a correct and well defined test result and report format, which should be generated automatically generate after a test run and show the results in an easy-to-read format. The reports should provide specifics about where application failures occurred and what test data was used. Reporting method like log reports and application screenshot at each step would be helpful in defining and highlighting any discrepancies and provide detailed explanations of each checkpoint pass and failure. Reports must also be easily shared across the entire QA and development teams. 10. Environment to support the test framework: This would include a continuous build system to launch a test suite at will, on schedule, or even after another event has occurred. With this environment, you can also run different suites of tests, such as smoke tests, functional tests, or browser-based tests. 11. Test Script and Coding Standards : The framework should define proper coding and scripting standards. This concept encourages testers to write code in an object-oriented manner. This allows reusable code to be incorporated throughout any given test. It can also assist in set-up tasks, such as preparing an environment or creating or refreshing database tables. The framework should define standards which would be helpful in making the test scripts consistent, readable and easily maintainable. 12. Maintenance friendly and proper documentation: The framework should be designed in such a way that it must be easy to use and maintain. By keeping clean code in an organized fashion, it becomes more of a tool than a hindrance. Documentation is always helpful when using the framework. What I have mentioned are a rough definition, and the points to be considered should not stop here. I found a useful link which defines these points in a separate points- Guidelines for Automation framework design

name: testerops
headline: With the advancement of scientific techniques and use of new machines and tools, we have been able to do a lot of good. Modern pharmaceuticals are one of the n-examples of this.
content: With the advancement of scientific techniques and use of new machines and tools, we have been able to do a lot of good. Modern pharmaceuticals are one of the n-examples of this. Due to the use of new methods, techniques, tools, we have been able to eradicate and in many scenarios, at least able to control the damage done by various life-threatening diseases. But, even with all this technology by our side, the overall process of developing a drug is still something which takes a lot of time effort and finance. Due to this, pharmaceutical research is in a terrible bottleneck. It may take about 10 years and $1 billion in finances to create a new drug, which is a costly and time taking affair. As such, while pharma companies struggle to develop medicines, even for rich countries, and tropical diseases like Malaria, African Sleeping Sickness , Chagas Disease continue to be ignored and overlooked, because the cost and speed of drug discovery and the economic return makes them unattractive options for the pharma industry. But the scenario is slowly changing. More and more use of automation techniques and tools are coming up, which are making the tedious and time taking work of the chemists a lot easier. A perfect example of this blend of automation and scientific mind is the robot scientist-Eve. Eve is a robotic scientist, a culmination of minds of brilliant professors and researchers at University of Aberystwyth and Cambridge . Eveâ€™s developers believe their Artificial Intelligence (AI) technology could speed up drug discovery, as she was created specifically to automate the early stages of drug design. It automates early-stage drug testing and design by using a series of tests that lend themselves to machine-screening at low cost at a rate of 10,000 tests a day.The AI-enabled robot is designed to add a new,advanced ability to learn, on top of all the other computation prowess that is uses. Instead of relying simply on brute-force testing of all available compounds, Eve takes a random subset of compounds, testing them a number of times to eliminate false results. Positive results are then analyzed using statistics and machine learning to predict new small molecule structures that are likely to return better results. The $1 million robot is designed in a way that eases itâ€™s work pressure and allows it to operate with more freedom. It has two robotic arms- that are controlled by a computer server- that dance midst equipment for dispensing liquids into plastic plates containing large numbers of wells. These plates are then used in screening tests for potentially useful drug compounds. Drug molecules, in essence, act like tiny keys that slot into protein or enzyme locks. In the plates, each well holds a biochemical system containing a lock, and when a key fits into it the system triggers a detectable signal such as fluorescence. Initial signalsâ€”or hitsâ€”are usually found on one instrument before further tests are done elsewhere to check if the key really does fit the lock.Eve integrates these usually separate capabilities, accelerating the research process. How? Scientists use an existing mathematical model- called â€œ Quantitative Structureâ€“Activity Relationship â€œ (QSAR), which relates how a moleculeâ€™s composition, shape and properties such as electrical charge to how well it fits the lock. The model is fine, but even with all the computation power, itâ€™s a method of slow trial-and-error. This is where Eveâ€™s AI comes into play. The AI-contains a set of â€œa ctive learning â€ capabilities, added over the conventional QSAR. The AI â€œlearnsâ€ the characteristics of the keys, that would fit in the locks, by combing a set of about 5000 molecules. It then uses those characteristics, to predict which remaining numbers of collection- are likely to be hits or misses. According to the journal they published in The Royal Society this February, Eve discovered that a compound once investigated as a potential anti-cancer drug can block DHFR , a molecule found in the malaria parasite. Although treatments against the molecules exits, the researchers point out that , scientists are always looking for alternatives in case the parasites develop a resistance to conventional treatments. â€œ Despite extensive efforts, no one has been able to find a new antimalarial that targets DHFR and is able to pass clinical trials ,â€ says Professor Ross King, from the Manchester Institute of Biotechnology. â€œEveâ€™s discovery could be even more significant than just demonstrating a new approach to drug discovery.â€ So why choose automation? Why use a robot in the already tried and tested human approach ? Professor King says â€œ Every industry now benefits from automation and science is no exception. Bringing in machine learning to make this process intelligent â€” rather than just a â€˜brute forceâ€™ approach â€” could greatly speed up scientific progress and potentially reap huge rewards .â€ . And obviously there are economic and effort benefits as well- commercial screening compounds are sold for around $15 per milligram, which is 10 times the price of gold. But such an effort comes with some critics and challenges as well. As Dr King cites- Eve currently does not have the capability to synthesize compounds that it can design based on its tests. Also the AI is still young, and sheâ€™s bound to go through more upgrades before she gets to help out more scientists and companies. Besides, critics like Derek Lowe, who runs a medical discovery blog called In The Pipeline , feels Eve â€œ seems like a natural consequence of the technologies we use already,â€ he says. â€œAs with any automated system, my worry about Eve is that people will take its results at face value, never bothering to look under the hood â€. There are many critics, who want a face-off between a robot scientist like Eve and a real world chemist to see how it performs against them. Also the steep price of Eve- it costs $1 million per unit, and the technical know-how to maintain it, alone would dampen the spirits of some companies. Despite all these criticism and challenges, the team is optimistic of Eveâ€™s abilities and the role it will be able to play in coming years. â€œ In the future AI systems will be deciding what to make and screen because theyâ€™re just better at some tasks than humans ,â€ he says.

name: testerops
headline: LinkedIn-as soon as we hear this name- professionals, jobs are the first two words that comes to everyone's minds. Not only it is a great place to turn in case you were looking for a job change or a job hunt, but it is actually a great place for someone to receive feedback, recommendations, inspirat
content: LinkedIn-as soon as we hear this name- professionals, jobs are the first two words that comes to everyone's minds. Not only it is a great place to turn in case you were looking for a job change or a job hunt, but it is actually a great place for someone to receive feedback, recommendations, inspiration, ideas, constructive criticism, professional lessons, and many more. In short, you'll get all the things that you need to gain from your professional network, through LinkedIn, and that too from the very comfort of your bed, sofa, or even your very own smartphone, anywhere in the world. In an online social networking platform, which is bustling with all kinds of professionals and users, it is important to build a good persona. It is crucial to get recognized among the plethora of people among the same career paths. But, this recognition or identity should not compromise on the very foundation of LinkedIn, which is professionalism. Whatever you do, or want to achieve, should be done, keeping in mind this very fact. And now a days, it seems many people are taking this very lightly, or at least seem to ignore the fact, that though, LinkedIn is a social network, it is not Facebook, or MySpace or Twitter. Over the past one-one and a half year, I have noticed a not-so-welcome change in the user base of LinkedIn. And this reflects directly in the LinkedIn feed that I have, which I see almost daily. And let me give you a brief show down of these posts- most of which are annoying and lack any sense of professionalism The Whatsapp group post. This is the most annoying kind of posts that I see now a days. And it's increasing day by day. In my daily feed, I can almost see one new Whatsapp group creation post everyday, where somebody would ask for the contact numbers, in pre-text of creating a group for helping people get jobs or for people from specific industry and so-on. I don't know how successful these groups are, but to me it seems plain old way of scamming/spamming and collecting phone numbers. The HashTag post. First it was Twitter, then Facebook, and now the trend seems to have caught up with LinkedIn too. We get it that some people think hashtags are cool way of describing what you're doing, but please do not make it laced with hash tags. It doesn't looks professional at all to me (may be I am old fashioned). Let me give you an example. I #completed my #Nyears with #SoAndSoCompany. #FeelingItWasJustYesterday. #LookingForManyMoreYears Please decide it for yourselves how good it sounds-considering the fact that gives your professional snapshot. Non-sense pictures post. While on one hand, I am a fan of having motivational posters and pictures posted, I am seriously bugged by people, who posts all kinds of non-sense pictures on here. Hopeless romatics posting romantic poems about their love and failure, the whatsapp pictures and the most annoying- decode this picture. Ugh! Please Stop! Ads/Contests This may be acceptable up to a certain point, but I have seen a lot of folks posting about contests, where the company would award 10 ipads or such to winning candidates. Primarily , all these are ads/spam posts and if by any chance, you have followed somebody from the company or the company itself, ruins the whole experience. Fake Profile posts. Not a new issue for any social networking website. But over the last year, I have seen a dramatic increase in no. of fake profiles. Posts about jobs abroad, and for folks with less skill set- seems to be the primary area of target for these fake profiles. A prime SEO tactic, it would seem. And the worst of it, is that it is done from a fake HR's profile- which have a beautiful girl's picture and lots of posts about hiring and such.Beware! Like Posts. " If you see God in this pic, please like it ". " Believers will surely like this pic ". Please stop making these kinds of stupid posts and posting all kinds of crap about this. We get that you believe in god, but this is not the place where you boast about it or ask other people to follow what you believe in.

name: inves7
headline: The global financial system is increasingly concentrated in the hands of a few asset management giants whose decisions shape capital flows, market sentiment, and long-term investment trends worldwide.
content: The global financial system is increasingly concentrated in the hands of a few asset management giants whose decisions shape capital flows, market sentiment, and long-term investment trends worldwide. Today, a small group of institutions manages an extraordinary share of global wealth, influencing equities, bonds, infrastructure projects, private markets, and even commodity demand. Among the most dominant players: â€¢ BlackRock â€” approx. $13.5T AUM The largest asset manager in the world, with a powerful footprint across ETFs, institutional mandates, and risk management technology. Its scale gives it structural influence over global asset allocation. â€¢ Vanguard â€” approx. $11.6T AUM A pioneer of passive investing, driving the global expansion of low-cost index funds and reshaping how millions of investors access markets. â€¢ Fidelity Investments â€” approx. $6.8T AUM A major force in active management, retirement solutions, and brokerage services, with strong positioning across both retail and institutional segments. â€¢ UBS â€” approx. $6.6T AUM One of the strongest global wealth management platforms, with deep penetration in Europe, Asia, and high-net-worth advisory. â€¢ State Street â€” approx. $5.45T AUM A cornerstone of institutional asset servicing and ETF management, playing a critical role in market infrastructure. â€¢ JPMorganChase Asset Management â€” approx. $4.6T AUM A global powerhouse combining active strategies, alternatives, and institutional distribution. â€¢ Goldman Sachs Asset Management â€” approx. $3.45T AUM Strong positioning in alternatives, private markets, and high-end institutional mandates. â€¢ Capital Group â€” approx. $3T AUM One of the oldest and most respected active managers, with a long-term investment philosophy. These firms are not just managing capital â€” they are shaping global economic direction. Their allocation decisions impact liquidity, valuations, capital access for companies, and the evolution of entire sectors. Understanding where capital concentrates is essential to understanding where markets move next. ğŸ’ INVEST Magazine â€” Coming Soon! Stay ahead of global markets with smart insights, strategy, and analysis from top financial thinkers. Get your free access to the next issue of INVEST Magazine and discover how investors worldwide are navigating markets. ğŸ‘‰ Subscribe now on LinkedIn: https://lnkd.in/dYywATTR ğŸ“ˆ INVEST â€” Knowledge is your best investment. Sources: Fiscal.ai , public disclosures from major asset managers #Investing #AssetManagement #WealthManagement #GlobalFinance #CapitalMarkets #InstitutionalInvestors #INVEST #Inves7

name: testerops
headline: Career advice is in no short supply. In fact, you could probably spend the duration of your working life simply reading through the tips and advice already online.
content: Career advice is in no short supply . In fact, you could probably spend the duration of your working life simply reading through the tips and advice already online. But as in all areas of life, the more common something is, generally speaking, the lower its value. Many oft repeated truisms are more about wish fulfillment than reality (sorry peddlers of endless, uncritical "follow your passion!" posts ). Plus, tips that everyone and their mother (and their college career counselor) knows are unlikely to give you an edge over the competition. So what are the true hidden gems of career advice, the truths that few people are willing to say out loud that can actually transform a mediocre career into a rockstar one? That's what a someone on question-and-answer site Quora wanted to know recently, asking: " What are a few unique pieces of career advice that nobody ever mentions ?" The community responded with plenty of uncommon, thought-provoking advice. Doing Your Job Well Is Not Enough Being excellent at your job is a surefire way to get ahead, right? Nope, say several responders, including Victor Wong, CEO of PaperG. "Most people assume just doing their current assigned job well is enough--so many associates at law firms think doing all the paperwork and litigation properly is the road to partnership, and many PR account executives think that getting a few articles written about their clients will earn them a promotion," he writes, but "becoming a principal, partner, or senior executive with P&L-level responsibility requires a completely separate set of skills from entry and mid-level jobs." How do you make that leap? "To make the big jump to the next level, they're really being benchmarked on their ability to deliver future value to the firm in ways that are not taught or explained to them: chiefly how much business are they are able to bring in," he asserts. "People who can think of what to do and deliver are the ones who ultimately are more likely to get promoted to the top levels." Another anonymous poster agrees: "You don't become a star doing your job. You become a star making things happen." Who You Work For Is Hugely Important We all wish we lived in a world where who you know matters less than what you can do, but that's often not reality, and not always for unhealthy reasons. Knowing the best in the business often means you've worked with the best, and people rightly admire that. "You don't have to be passionate about the product you are selling. You don't have to be in the most glamorous industry. You don't have to work for the company with the best 'brand' identity or reputation in your chosen field," insists Jeremy Boudinet, director of marketing for startup Ambition. What does matter is who you've worked with. "Few things are as valuable as going and working for somebody that is going to want to teach you anything and everything they know. You'll experience tremendous personal and professional growth if you have the best person mentoring you ," he says, so "figure out where the absolute best person to work for would be, and go work for them." ... So Is Where You Work Just like who you work for can deeply affect the fate of your career, where you work also has a massive impact. Just saying, 'I want to work in software or sales,' isn't enough. Nor, as Boudinet point out, is it enough just to fill your resume with impressive company names. Your destiny is influenced greatly by the destiny of the particular organization that employs you. Don't take a job with just any old company because it's in the right sector or impresses your friends. "Your career is a boat and it is at the mercy of tides. No matter how talented you are it's a lot harder to break out in a sluggish situation/hierarchy/economy than a go-go environment. Even if you're a superstar at Sluggish Co., your upside trajectory (more often than not) is fractional to what an average/below average employee achieves at Rocket Ship Co," says an anonymous poster with the most up-voted answer. Being Seen as Super Busy Isn't Always a Good Thing Think high achievers work endless hours and are continuously busy ? Think again, writes Mira Zaslove, director of international sales and trading at FabExchange. "Ironically the busier you appear, often the less you will move up. I've seen smart and dedicated employees fail to get promoted, because they have taken on too much, are working too hard, and appeared too frazzled," she reports. "If you appear stressed, people will think you aren't prepared to take on more, and you'll miss opportunities for new and innovative projects." Take a Tour When plotting your first (or next) big career move, many of us think very abstractly, musing in solitude or in front of Google about the joys of our supposed dream jobs. But the truth is you can't decide on a career without seeing the day-to-day reality of where and how you work --the concrete truth rather than the imagined reality. Don't make decisions without actually going and seeing for yourself. Alek Mirkovich, founder of campayn.com, once thought becoming an air traffic controller was a great idea, but then he took a tour of where he would actually be working. "Every single guy was BALD! Playing around with a simulator is fun but apparently the real thing is stressful. Within 30 seconds I knew I wasn't going to be signing up for this!" he remembers. Don't Hide Your Failures Failures are seen less as a signal of incompetence and more as a sign that you're willing to take a risk and innovate, according to Zaslove. "Your team will respect you and your career will accelerate if people understand what you are doing and that you are taking risks. Most people do not view someone as credible if they are giving advice and recommendations, but not walking the walk," she claims. "If you show that you are willing to take risks, and publicly falter, your team will feel confident taking risks too. Lead by example." Execution Matters More Than Plans or Advice Many people are looking for the magic recipe of how to make their career take off, but many of the responders agree that there are some serious limits to what other people can tell you. "Advice (like ideas) is not in short supply, there is plenty of it going around," writes coach Darren Beattie, for instance. "It's not really the advice in the long run that matters, it's the execution of the advice by the person being advised. The greatest advice ever in the history of the human race is absolutely useless if you act/execute on none of it." Or to put it another way, there's no real roadmap that you can blindly follow . The trick is figuring out what to apply and what to ignore for your own personal situation. That same popular anonymous responder sums this idea up well: "Career tracks and meritocracies don't exist: Your career is not a linear, clearly defined trajectory." What less well known bit of career wisdom would you add to this list?

name: testerops
headline: The 8th Annual Crunchies Awards, hosted by TechCrunch kicked off at Davies Symphony Hall yesterday night. The Crunchies Awards ,hosted by TechCrunch and Venture Beat recognizes and celebrates the most compelling start ups, internet and technological innovations all over the year.
content: The 8th Annual Crunchies Awards, hosted by TechCrunch kicked off at Davies Symphony Hall yesterday night. The Crunchies Awards ,hosted by TechCrunch and Venture Beat recognizes and celebrates the most compelling start ups, internet and technological innovations all over the year. The Awards brought a range of start-ups and innovations round the year to the front of the online tech community. This year Slack seemed to be the major winner, as it was nominated in at least 4 different categories ( Fastest Rising Start-Up , Best Enterprise Start-Up , Founder of The Year , Best New Start-Up of The Year ). It ended up winning the award for the Founder of The Year with Stewart Butterfield , Eric Coestello , Carl Henderson and Sergei Mourachov winning this award. Rising and controversial start-up Yik Yak beat competition from Slack and Reddit , to win the Fastest Rising Start-Up of The Year , while the Airbnb design team brought laurels to the company by winning the Best Design segment. On international front, popular messaging app Line , trounced competitors like Spotify , Kik to take home the Best International Start-Up . On technology and hardware front, Occulus VR won the Best Hardware Start-Up , while Best Technology Achievement went to Stella-Solar Powered Car, which beat competition from Apple Pay and Rosettaâ€™s Comet Landing. On personal front, Jim Goetz of Sequioa Capital won the Venture Capitalist of the Year award, while Salesforce.com CEO Marc Benioff won the CEO of the Year award. Complete List of Award Winners : Best Technology Achievement Winner : Stella Solar-Powered Car Best On-Demand Service Winner : Hotel Tonight Best E-Commerce Application Winner : Casper Best Mobile Application Winner : Storehouse Fastest-Rising Startup Winner : Yik Yak Best Health Startup Winner : Theranos Best Design Winner: Airbnb Best Bootstrapped Startup Winner: Meadow Best Enterprise Startup Winner: CloudFlare Best International Startup Winner: Line Best Education Startup Winner: ClassDojo Best Hardware Startup Winner: Oculus VR Canâ€™t Stop, Wonâ€™t Stop Winner: Kim Kardashian: Hollywood Biggest Social Impact Winner: Twitter Angel of the Year Winner: Kickstarter Backers of Oculus VR VC of the Year Winner: Jim Goetz (Sequoia Capital) Founder of the Year Winner: Stewart Butterfield, Eric Costello, Cal Henderson and Serguei Mourachov (Slack) CEO of the Year Winner: Marc Benioff (Salesforce.com) Best New Startup of 2014 Winner: Product Hunt Best Overall Startup of 2014 Winner: Uber For a more detailed list of all award winners along with the runner-ups and finalists, head over to TechCrunchâ€™s page .
